habitat: Grows in shelf-like clusters on both dead and living hardwood; widely distributed in forests of North America and worldwide. Fruits from late spring through September.
shortDescription: An edible oyster mushroom closely related to Pleurotus ostreatus. It has smaller, paler caps, more developed stems, and prefers warmer conditions. Cultivated in Europe and North America.
edibility: Edible and widely cultivated. Considered a healthy food, low in calories, fat, and sodium.
benefitsOrToxicity: Contains β-D-Glucan with analgesic properties. Extracts show anti-inflammatory, antitumor, antihyperglycemic, antihypertensive, antioxidant, antiviral, and antiallergic activities. Potential use in cancer therapy, diabetes management, and cardiovascular support. May cause gastrointestinal distress due to arabitol in sensitive individuals.

identification.cap: 3–10 cm; convex to flat or slightly depressed; fan-shaped to semicircular; whitish to beige or pale tan; smooth, bald, sometimes greasy when fresh; margin inrolled when young, later wavy.
identification.gills: Decurrent; close to nearly distant; whitish, turning yellowish with age.
identification.stem: 0.5–1 cm thick, 1–4 cm long; eccentric, lateral, or central; whitish, smooth; may be rudimentary or absent.
identification.taste: Mild mushroom flavor, slight anise note.
identification.microscopicFeatures: Spores 7–11 × 2–3 µm, cylindric-ellipsoid, smooth, hyaline in KOH, inamyloid. Hymenial cystidia absent. Pileipellis a cutis with 5–10 µm wide hyaline elements.

medicinalProperties: Research indicates anticancer, antihypertensive (ACE inhibition), antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antidiabetic, antirhinitis, and antiviral (including HIV-1 RT inhibition) effects. Polysaccharide-protein complexes and metabolites show immunomodulatory activity and potential therapeutic applications.
note: Also cultivated for environmental uses such as biodegradable packaging, oil spill cleanup, and even disposable diaper degradation. Naturally contains lovastatin, associated with cholesterol reduction.
